name: StreamController
comment:
A controller with the stream it controls.

This controller allows sending data, error and done events on its dart-async.StreamController.stream. This class can be used to create a simple stream that others can listen on, and to push events to that stream.

It's possible to check whether the stream is paused or not, and whether it has subscribers or not, as well as getting a callback when either of these change.

If the stream starts or stops having listeners (first listener subscribing, last listener unsubscribing), the onSubscriptionStateChange callback is notified as soon as possible. If the subscription stat changes during an event firing or a callback being executed, the change will not be reported until the current event or callback has finished. If the pause state has also changed during an event or callback, only the subscription state callback is notified.

If the subscriber state has not changed, but the pause state has, the onPauseStateChange callback is notified as soon as possible, after firing a current event or completing another callback. This happens if the stream is not paused, and a listener pauses it, or if the stream has been resumed from pause and has no pending events. If the listeners resume a paused stream while it still has queued events, the controller will still consider the stream paused until all queued events have been dispatched.

Whether to invoke a callback depends only on the state before and after a stream action, for example firing an event. If the state changes multiple times during the action, and then ends up in the same state as before, no callback is performed.

If listeners are added after the stream has completed (sent a "done" event), the listeners will be sent a "done" event eventually, but they won't affect the stream at all, and won't trigger callbacks. From the controller's point of view, the stream is completely inert when has completed.

stream.name: stream
stream.comment: The stream that this controller is controlling.

sink.name: sink
sink.comment: Returns a view of this object that only exposes the dart-async.StreamSink interface.

isClosed.name: isClosed
isClosed.comment:
Whether the stream is closed for adding more events.

If true, the "done" event might not have fired yet, but it has been scheduled, and it is too late to add more events.

isPaused.name: isPaused
isPaused.comment:
Whether the subscription would need to buffer events.

This is the case if the controller's stream has a listener and it is paused, or if it has not received a listener yet. In that case, the controller is considered paused as well.

A broadcast stream controller is never considered paused. It always forwards its events to all uncanceled listeners, if any, and let them handle their own pausing.

hasListener.name: hasListener
hasListener.comment: Whether there is a subscriber on the dart-async.Stream.

constructors.comment:
A controller with a dart-async.StreamController.stream that supports only one single subscriber.

If dart-async.StreamController.StreamController-.sync is true, events may be passed directly to the stream's listener during an add, dart-async.StreamController.addError or close call. If dart-async.StreamController.StreamController-.sync is false, the event will be passed to the listener at a later time, after the code creating the event has returned.

The controller will buffer all incoming events until the subscriber is registered.

The dart-async.StreamController.StreamController-.onPause function is called when the stream becomes paused. dart-async.StreamController.StreamController-.onResume is called when the stream resumed.

The dart-async.StreamController.StreamController-.onListen callback is called when the stream receives its listener and dart-async.StreamController.StreamController-.onCancel when the listener ends its subscription. If dart-async.StreamController.StreamController-.onCancel needs to perform an asynchronous operation, dart-async.StreamController.StreamController-.onCancel should return a future that completes when the cancel operation is done.

If the stream is canceled before the controller needs new data the dart-async.StreamController.StreamController-.onResume call might not be executed.

broadcast.name: broadcast
broadcast.comment:
A controller where dart-async.StreamController.stream can be listened to more than once.

The dart-async.Stream returned by dart-async.StreamController.stream is a broadcast stream. It can be listened to more than once.

The controller distributes any events to all currently subscribed listeners at the time when add, dart-async.StreamController.addError or close is called. It is not allowed to call add, addError, or close before a previous call has returned. The controller does not have any internal queue of events, and if there are no listeners at the time the event is added, it will just be dropped, or, if it is an error, be reported as uncaught.

Each listener subscription is handled independently, and if one pauses, only the pausing listener is affected. A paused listener will buffer events internally until unpaused or canceled.

If dart-async.StreamController.StreamController-broadcast.sync is true, events may be fired directly by the stream's subscriptions during an add, dart-async.StreamController.addError or close call. If dart-async.StreamController.StreamController-broadcast.sync is false, the event will be fired at a later time, after the code adding the event has completed.

When dart-async.StreamController.StreamController-broadcast.sync is false, no guarantees are given with regard to when multiple listeners get the events, except that each listener will get all events in the correct order. Each subscription handles the events individually. If two events are sent on an async controller with two listeners, one of the listeners may get both events before the other listener gets any. A listener must be subscribed both when the event is initiated (that is, when add is called) and when the event is later delivered, in order to receive the event.

The dart-async.StreamController.StreamController-broadcast.onListen callback is called when the first listener is subscribed, and the dart-async.StreamController.StreamController-broadcast.onCancel is called when there are no longer any active listeners. If a listener is added again later, after the dart-async.StreamController.StreamController-broadcast.onCancel was called, the dart-async.StreamController.StreamController-broadcast.onListen will be called again.

addError.name: addError
addError.comment:
Send or enqueue an error event.

Also allows an objection stack trace object, on top of what dart-async.EventSink allows.

addStream.name: addStream
addStream.comment:
Receives events from dart-async.StreamController.addStream.source and puts them into this controller's stream.

Returns a future which completes when the source stream is done.

Events must not be added directly to this controller using add, dart-async.StreamController.addError, close or dart-async.StreamController.addStream, until the returned future is complete.

Data and error events are forwarded to this controller's stream. A done event on the source will end the addStream operation and complete the returned future.

If dart-async.StreamController.addStream.cancelOnError is true, only the first error on dart-async.StreamController.addStream.source is forwarded to the controller's stream, and the addStream ends after this. If dart-async.StreamController.addStream.cancelOnError is false, all errors are forwarded and only a done event will end the addStream.

hashCode.name: hashCode
hashCode.comment:
Get a hash code for this object.

All objects have hash codes. Hash codes are guaranteed to be the same for objects that are equal when compared using the equality operator ==. Other than that there are no guarantees about the hash codes. They will not be consistent between runs and there are no distribution guarantees.

If a subclass overrides dart-async.StreamController.hashCode it should override the equality operator as well to maintain consistency.

runtimeType.name: runtimeType
runtimeType.comment: A representation of the runtime type of the object.

done.name: done
done.comment:
The dart-async.StreamController.done Future completes with the same values as dart-async.StreamController.close, except for the following case:

  • The synchronous methods of dart-async.EventSink were called, resulting in an error. If there is no active future (like from an addStream call), the dart-async.StreamController.done future will complete with that error

==.comment:
The equality operator.

The default behavior for all dart-core.Objects is to return true if and only if this and dart-async.StreamController.==.other are the same object.

Override this method to specify a different equality relation on a class. The overriding method must still be an equivalence relation. That is, it must be:

  • Total: It must return a boolean for all arguments. It should never throw or return null.

  • Reflexive: For all objects o, o == o must be true.

  • Symmetric: For all objects o1 and o2, o1 == o2 and o2 == o1 must either both be true, or both be false.

  • Transitive: For all objects o1, o2, and o3, if o1 == o2 and o2 == o3 are true, then o1 == o3 must be true.

The method should also be consistent over time, so equality of two objects should not change over time, or at least only change if one of the objects was modified.

If a subclass overrides the equality operator it should override the dart-async.StreamController.hashCode method as well to maintain consistency.

toString.name: toString
toString.comment: Returns a string representation of this object.

noSuchMethod.name: noSuchMethod
noSuchMethod.comment:
dart-async.StreamController.noSuchMethod is invoked when users invoke a non-existent method on an object. The name of the method and the arguments of the invocation are passed to dart-async.StreamController.noSuchMethod in an dart-core.Invocation. If dart-async.StreamController.noSuchMethod returns a value, that value becomes the result of the original invocation.

The default behavior of dart-async.StreamController.noSuchMethod is to throw a dart-core.NoSuchMethodError.

addStream.name: addStream
addStream.comment:
Consumes the elements of dart-async.StreamController.addStream.stream.

Listens on dart-async.StreamController.addStream.stream and does something for each event.

The consumer may stop listening after an error, or it may consume all the errors and only stop at a done event.
